It's Here!
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 4 Archive (PS2): Monster Farm 4 (Spoilers!): Reviews, Information on Gameplay, Etc. : It's Here!
By Lisa Shock on Monday, August 18, 2003 - 10:48 pm:

I just got home from work, and have the game! I will play for about an hour and post more in a little while! Also, the game manual has some pictures of monsters we haven't really seen, including the new Ogyo, Ripper and Madillo. I will post a scan of those tomorrow morning.

By Lisa Shock on Monday, August 18, 2003 - 11:56 pm:

The intro is a short anime sequence, with a woman singing to music in the background, sort of like a long version of a movie intro. It shows the game characters interacting with monsters, Fan runs around with Golem, Mocchi, and Suezo. It shows a variety of situations, including that "pirate Gaboo". (His hook turns into a mace at one point.) We see the Phoenix at the very end of the intro, and it flys away. It's almost as if Tecmo wanted to take over the old cartoon show, and write it themselves.

The game itself has an intro about the characters, and shows you a bit of town before letting you into the shrine and then onto the ranch. I made a Garu, I wasn't offered the option to try a CD right away. (If I was, I completely missed it!)

Some facts: Your character can run around the ranch in 3D.
You start with 4 items available: Potato, Mango, Squid and Meat.
There is an Encyclopedia.
Skill is back.
Techs are pretty much the same, the chart that displays them looks different. They can have attributes like in MR3; designation icons show you if it's a fire/water/beat type tech.
The music is sort of bland, and notably missing are many of the old themes.
Menus are a little different, but easy enough to navigate.

Well, that's about it for now. I haven't had time to do much yet (no battling or exploring) but I will be posting more in days to come!

By Raistlin_Majere on Tuesday, August 19, 2003 - 12:04 am:

during the first part ur not offered to pop in a CD in the tray (its part of the story line) that your supposed to have an enbanseki (disc slate) which contains the Garu/Gafu(?) as ur first monster. (Just the same as the animation / video sequence :) ). As you play the game don't forget to get the data from the monster rancher 4 disc (the CD acts as a pandora disc too ) you'll be able to get the 3 rare antlans from there. Once you get the slating option try the Monster Rancher 4 disc so u'll get a blue antlan. Once you win a tournament or reach monster rank D and breeder rank E, you'll be able to get the Yellow Antlan. That is if i remember it correctly :)

By Lisa Shock on Tuesday, August 19, 2003 - 09:47 am:

So far, I have only rested my monster for 3 weeks. And, oddly enough, it's 'energy' went down! I need to figure out how to add drills, hopefully tonight, and I will post more. (I didn't have a lot of time to play last night. I'll have a little more tonight.)

And, yes, gas is over $3 a gallon here now....

By Raistlin_Majere on Tuesday, August 19, 2003 - 05:04 pm:

the energy would go down even just by resting but the stress / fatigue level would remain the same to maintain ur monster's energy level you need to feed it from time to time. I'm having a problem with the feeding system with the antlans co'z when I'm training them once they get to "yase" or thin they easily get irritated or stressed out and if they get "debu" or fat they easily get tired when i'm drilling them.

As for adding more drills after you win a few battles you the carpenter would drop by and offer you his services where u could purchase training gadgets. There's another carpenter, female, who would upgrade your house and facility to which you could train more monsters :) (1st upgrade allows u to train 3 monsters, 2nd upgrade enables u to train 5 monsters :)

By Raistlin_Majere on Tuesday, August 19, 2003 - 05:14 pm:

About training gadgets: The special training gadgets can be acquired via adventures also special facilities for ur farm. These training gadgets are acquired as slates during adventures to which you would give them to the carpenter for study and the carpenter would add them into his/her inventory for you to buy :)

sorry if i keep forgetting to add information, sometimes it just passes my mind and i keep forgetting to type it in :(

By Nate Railsback on Wednesday, August 20, 2003 - 11:48 pm:

Ah, still only 8-space names? Crap. It may not seem like much, but having 8 instead of 10 REALLY cuts down on many of the names I would have liked to have given to my MR3 monsters. But, SKILL IS BACK, and that satisfies me. Also, you said that the techs "are pretty much the same"-- considering that they're handled differently in the MR 1/2, MRA 1/2, and MR3, how do you mean? Can you have all like in MR1/2, do you only get 4 at a time like in MR3, or did they do the compromise "equipping" system of the Advance games? Since I'm a big fan of having a wide move list, this is very important to me.

By Raistlin_Majere on Thursday, August 21, 2003 - 05:01 am:

you can actually have 12 moves in your total list but you can only equip 9 for battling purposes. To access them you just press R1 or R2 for scrolling.

3 moves for long range
3 moves for medium range
3 moves for short range or melee
